On tap at Coles  
Aroma mild aroma, slight hint of amber malt. Not much behind.
 Appearance  decent appearance. Medium plus carbonation, deep amber gold in colour. Good long lasting creamy top.
Flavor and Palate : Nutty, clean, oily body. Finishing nutty as well with solid malt base. Not overly sweet.

Bottle, as pictured.  Pours an orange-amber with minimal head.  Smell is sweet - caramel, toffee, some fruit (grape, maybe?).  Taste is similar, very smooth and easy to drink.  Certainly not a fizzy mouthfeel.  Pretty good overall.
A little too malty and sweet for me.  Not a bad red beer, but not a big fan overall.

12 oz. pours clear light amber in color with almost no head just a ring around the glass. A small amount of caramel and some spice but there is a funkiness there as well. I taste some malty sweetness and biscuit it almost tastes like a lighter version of their christmas ale. Mouthfeel is light with medium carbination and the finish is a little short.

Tap.  Reddish copper in color with a small white head.  Doughy caramel aroma.  Very sweet caramel flavor with some breadiness, and a minimal bitter finish.  Medium bodied, and loads of lacing left on the glass.  Too sweet for me without some bitterness to help balance.
Tap. Clear brownish amber pour with a small white pour. Malty nose with mild caramel. Full mouthfeel. Taste is an odd malt and almost buttery. Caramel as well. Not crazy about this one.

12 oz bottle on St. Paddys day. Pours orange with off-white head that quickly dissipates. No lacing. Aroma is malty, flavor isnt anything special-- bready and sweet. Not a huge fan, but it is pretty drinkable and would serve as a nice session alternative to Guinness tonight.

Aroma: Hints of maltiness, but not much here. Almost have to stick your nose in the beer itself to get any aroma.
Appearance: Pale orange with little to no head.
Taste: Medium sweetness with faintly sour finish.
Palate: Medium body, creamy texture, slightly effervescent carbonation with decent finish.
Overall: A very tasty, drinkable beer that isnt cloyingly heavy or sweet. A solid St. Paddys Day treat.

Not expecting much here just by the style.  Irish reds have never done much for me.  The pour is clear, reddish amber with fresh aromas of malt and caramel.  This is a light to medium bodied beer with flavors of lightly toasted caramel malts with a hint of nuttiness.  Refreshing and decent.
UPDATED: AUG 7, 2016 Had at the Grafton. A decent Irish ale but not as roasted a flavor as I would have expected. A slight tang that didnt agree with me.  However overall not bad. Serving: Tap

Darker Orange with an off-white colored head. Balance of hops and malts in aroma. Sweet, grain, bread flavor. A little heavier than expected. Would be good with stew or some other meal that might be served with bread.

Rating #333, thats halfway to the sign of the antichrist.  Scary.  Ive also had a lot to drink.  Clear amber color, solid white head.  Aroma of bread dough and wet socks, but in a good way.  Taste is like Ovaltine on rye bread.  Tasty.

12oz bottle from Pies and Pints. Pours clear amber with small white head. Aromas of toasted malts, bit of bread, and caramel. Flavors of toasted malts, bread, caramel, and a bit of nut. Easy drinking Irish Ale. Not bad.

(bottle) Pours a clear lighter amber with just a very thin off-white head.  Aroma certainly identifies itself as being brewed by Great Lakes, as that characteristic toasty, somewhat nutty smell is perceived right off the bat.  Other aromas of peanut butter sugar cookie and faint grapefruit hops.  Vigorous swirling really gets some fruit scents to emerge, but its difficult to place exactly what the scent is.  If I had to venture a guess, it would be an overripe plum.  Odd but also interesting.  Taste is strong of caramel, toasted malt, and really not much else.  Finish is lightly bitter with a faint, tea-like astringency.  Little bit of alcohol heat sweeps through on the finish.  Mouthfeel is medium and carbonation is good.  Not bad.
Pours redish brown with a noce head.  Nose is very malty with some fruit.  Taste was loaded with malt and a nice hop note.  One of the best irish ales i have ever had.

Poured from a bottle into a snifter. Appearance is a beautiful, translucent amber with a one finger, beige head that dissipates slowly and leaves behind splotchy lacing. Aroma is a toasty malt with some accents of wood and a touch of sugary sweetness. Taste is much like the nose: malty body up front fading to a floral hoppy note with some wood accents noticed in the aftertaste. Medium bodied and fully of flavor. Very nice for the style.

Poured from bottle.  Big malt aroma - smells like a brewery.  Beautiful amber with persistent head .  Malt and brown sugar flavor.  Cinnamon, banana and spice notes too.  Slightly sweet, but clean feel.  This is an Irish ale with something extra.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: Pours a completely translucent amber with a decent-sized but quickly receding white head.  Nose is cheap american beer (ie, not inviting).  Flavor is much better than the nose.  Creamy, nutty, malty, and a bit sweet.  I recall really loving this when I was younger, but my tastes have clearly changed quite a bit.  Still, this is a decent beer for a change of pace.  Ill continue to pick up a sixer or two when its released each year.

aroma of cereal malts, toffee, caramel and toast.
appearance is clear golden color with about 1 finger of head that disipates quickly.  slight amount of lace as drunk.
smooth on the palate with a restricted carbonation, very easy drinking for 6.5% abv.
taste is continuation of the aroma, lots of toffee and caramel with a subtle background bitterness that does not stick around.  nice dry finish true to style.  not getting very much in the way of hop presence which is surprising since i believe they are hopping this a little heavier than the style requires.
Extremely quaffable beer overall, almost reminds me of scotch ale but never the less a fine ale.
On draft at The Big Hunt in DC.  Pours a medium, clear red. Light hop on front, medium malt backbone. A decent beer that I would order, but not my favorite of GL seasonals.

amber pour with a thick off white head.
aroma is bready, slightly fruity. 
soft malty flavour caramel, toffee. light hoppiness. 
very smooth with no hint of the 6.5%

Appearance:  beautiful--crystal clear orange, with deep ruby notes and a nice one-finger light brown head; some lace. Aroma:  almost all malt--toasty, nutty and sweet with notes of caramel, fresh brown bread, molasses and toffee.  Taste:  as the aroma indicates--sweet, nutty and toasty with an emphasis on the malt profile.  Finish:  smooth, clean an surprisingly crisp.  Notes:  Nice malt-accented brew.  Could have been syrupy-sweet, but the palate was nicely balanced and crisp.  Good nutty and bready flavors.

Crisp dark orange color with a tight white head.  Theres nothing overpowering in this, and thats why I like it. It just tastes good! If you really want to search for flavors, youll get some bread, a little bit of roast, maybe a hint of apple (but not sour) at the end.

Simple, but very good.

Bottle. Pours light brown with an off-white head. Aroma of corn, grain husk, and some grassy hops. Flavor is medium bodied with a toasty sweet malt flavor and little bitterness followed with a clean finish.

355mL stolen from tastybeer. Pours a clear fire orange with a medium, dense, rocky, sheen, yellow head with pretty good retention and spotty lace. Aroma is corn heavy, reminds me of a grainy well-made lager, lots of sweet cherry, and that characteristic Great Lakes rustic/raw maltiness. Taste is suddy at first, moving to sweet cherries, moving to almost metallic, and finishing oatmeal grainy and crackery malt heavy. Really has an insane amount of malt husk and raw malt character that Great Lakes has in all of their beers. Just too suddy on the palate.

Aroma of caramel, nuts, and hops.  Very nice copper coloring with modertae copper head that slowly disipates.  Taste of strong hops and alcohol. Moderate mouth feel with livlely carbonation. Overall well made beer but not as good as many of Great Lakes fine offerings.
Clear amber color.  Very sweet aroma, brown sugar & caramel.  Taste is smooth & creamy with some malts and some more caramel aftertaste.  Might have to find a 5gal. for St Pattys day.

Pours a clear copper-amber color; two fingers of fine white head with decent retention; not much lacing. Smells of toasted malts, and amazingly like bread; definitely picking up more of a bread/toast flavor than with any other beer Ive had. Light caramel malt aroma; no hop presence here. Taste again starts off with bread, with a bit more of that caramel malt. A bit of floral hops on the finish, which provide balance to the beers lightly sweet flavors. Thin-medium body, moderate carbonation, very smooth.

On tap at the local option; pour is a dark clear golden with creamy off white head. Nice lacing on this one. Aroma is like sweet florals, but very light with a bit of toffee. Flavors are creamy maltiness initially, with an almost peat element. Toffee and a hint of fruit esters (banana) come through. So it is a bit sweet, but it is also a bit dry, yet it is also a bit bitter from the hops. Different but interesting

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2017 Sixer from Liquor Barn (Jefferson Commons); drink-by date of 4/15/17. Aroma: Moderate caramel biscuit and toast in balance; nearly moderate apple-skin fruit. Appearance: Well carbonated, transparent copper with a foamy bone head that settles into a patchy ring. Flavor: Toast and caramel biscuits abounds; some light candied citrus notes with a good bit of apple skin (yeast?) becoming more apparent towards the finish, which is semi-dry and barely bitter. Palate: Medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation, lingering finish. Overall: A bit of a head scratcher for me; good in some respects, especially the malt profile, but the hop/yeast combo comes off a little odd. Also, at 6.5%, this isnt ideal for a session, which seems out of character for this style, maybe 4.5-5% tops to be sessionable. Not my favorite GL offering, but by no means a bad beer.

$8 sixer - poured into pint glass and couldnt really detect any aroma.  My sense of smell isnt great, but I really couldnt detect an aroma.  Good looking amberish / light red beer that produces a thin, lasting head.  Toasted malt predominates, but other subtle flavors come through--just okay.  Not overexcited about this one, but would be very acceptable for sessions.

12oz bottle from a trade with phaleslu. Thanks Peter! Pours a crystal clear, copper-gold colored body with a finger-width, frothy, off-white head that dissipates quickly and leaves a moderate lacing. Aroma is at first a wet grain smell, almost like the smell of a mash. Upon second whiff, the sweeter caramels come out more with a bit of a toasted, nutty toffee. A faint apple-butter, herbal spice, and non-distinct hop. Flavor is much better. Sweet caramels and lightly toasted toffees greet the tongue before a wet grain, light grass, and some cherries come in. A few estery fruits thrown around as well as a touch of nutty spice. Finishes fairly crisp and dry with a very light bitterness and a medium length aftertaste. Light to medium body, very smooth, somewhat chewy at times, and a soft, moderate carbonation. Overall, not a bad Irish Ale. I think the wet grain works in the flavor much more so than the aroma. Malty, fruity, and lightly toasted/hopped that makes for a simple and sweet, but solid beer.
A decent beer, with a nice balance of hops and malty character.  But, really, not much going on here.

Acquired a 6 pack. Pours an amber color. Aroma is malty and something else that was faint, couldnt quite pick it out. Taste wasnt bad, a good session taste. It should complement "meat and potatoes" meal perfectly. Very well balanced I might add.

Had this on draft at the local BW3s because, well thats about all they had for craft beer. 16 oz glass with my chicken wings. Amber/Mahogany in color, nice head retains well. I picked up very little aroma from my glass, maybe a faint grassy aroma. Very malty with bitter rye notes.  Medium bodied with a bitter finish that reminded me of chocolate malt balls dipped in Irish Whiskey. This actually went well with my hot wings. Its got a little bit of bitter/sour aftertaste that would prevent me from having more than one, but its more than I expected for a place that doesnt normally serve craft beers.

12 oz. bottle via trade with miketd - Pours a crystal clear copper color with a small off white head.  No lacing.  Aroma is toasted malt.  Flavor is toasted malt and light esters.  Medium body.  A basic, easy drinking beer.  Thanks Mike.

Excellent.  Had this from tap.  Good roasted malt flavors wit ha complex hop profile.  Both highly malted and hopped There are slight hints of rasins.  Wonderful dark red color.  The beer is very clear.  Probably the best Red Irish Ale Ive had.  Very drinkable.  My Great Lakes Favorite to date.

12 oz Bottle -- Pours deep red-amber with a medium off-white head.  Toasted malts, roasted nuts, some slight caramel, and some buttered popcorn or flax seed on the nose.  Medium sweetness throughout with a slight bitterness on the finish.
12oz bottle. clear copper color and small, lasting head. slight caramel aroma. light malt taste, seems a little thin, but a decent beer
Malty red colored beer with notes of tea like hops, somewhat lively, medium bodied, but becomes heavy in mouthfeel and body as it warms... decent, but a bit odd with the tealike flavors...

Not a bad brew. Not what I was expecting. No nutty or carmel character. Somewhat of a malt and refreshing hop character to it though. I liked this brew overall but not the best Irish red I have ever had. I do recommend it as "worth a try". Its not bad overall.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-08-2007 00:36:02

Bottle - Pours clear amber with a frothy off-white head. Malty and doughy, with a hint of chocolate and a light earthy hop aroma. Taste is malt-forward with a light hazelnut note. Slight warming in the belly on the finish. Pleasant and smooth, itd be easy to drink a couple these no problem. The carbonation is jacked up a bit too much, but overall the slightly oily, medium body is nice.

Pours a deep rich copper/amber color with very little head and leaves no lacing behind.  Smells of sweet caramel and a bit of grass and brown sugar.  The flavor is of caramel, grass, and nice cereal grains.
Pours a nice red color with a thin head. Aroma is malty with a small hop undertone. Beer is refreshing, but finishes a bit malty for my taste.
Also on Tap at Fuel and Fuddle, very well balance malty ale with caramel notes, very little head and no lacing over the golden color.  Nice clean finish.
Cinnamon and candy aroma.  Wet, juicy mouthfeel.   slightly tart and fruity flavor. finishes dry.  Solid and nice to have had on Saint Patricks Day.

A dark amber ale with a thin off white head. In aroma, sweet fruity butterscotch, a bit muskey. In mouth, a boring ale with light hops, caramel malts, watery and non-descript.  Tasted at CNY brewfest, Feb. 6 2010.
From a bottle poured an amber color with a fair amount of head.  Bitter malty flavor with a lasting finish.
copper in color, malt and hop aroma. complex flavors, perhaps some fruit and caramel, not bitter. smooth with moderate carbonation.

Bottle from a trade with phaleslu. Pours clear copper color with off white head.  Toasted malt aroma with some nuttiness. Flavors of caramel, toasted malts and a bit nutty. Medium body wih soft carbonation. Thanks Peter.

Irish ales suck by nature, so for me this is easily the best irish ale on the planet. Toasted notes in the flavor and aroma, a little bit drying on the palate, but nothing major. Would be better if it were green

Dark amber color out of the bottle with a thin, short lived head.  Sweet, caramelly nose with some toasted grains.  Very malty beer, with lots of caramel, light toast, some toffee and sweetened tea.  Easy drinking beer that doesnt seem to be 6.5%.

Bottle.  Aroma is unique with a rich malty toasty note with a potent fruity character as well.  Dark amber in color with a whispy off-white head that leaves little to no lacing.  Flavor is a well balanced mix of caramely toasty malt and floral mildly bitter hops.  A bit thin on the palate.
Skunky and bad. Funky maltiness. Off flavors galore. Great leakes makes both good and terrible beers - why?
12oz bottle from Belmont Party Supply in Dayton, OH.  Amber ale color.  Very creamy and goes down super smooth.  Very solid beer just to kick back and drink.
On tap at Surly Girl Saloon.  Frothy off-white head, Malty flavor and amber orange in color.  6.5% ABV.  Good seasonal beer in a good bar on a cold day.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a glass.  Pours a light red with a medium size head that disapates quicky.  Not too much lacing and pretty good body.  Taste is lightly toasted barley with an aftertaste of spicy hops.

12 oz bottle.  Pours amber with an off-white head.  Aroma is sweet caramel, honey, biscuit, vague hints of some dark fruits.  Flavor has biscuit and caramel, maybe a slight hoppy touch in there.  Solid.

12 oz. bottle from Kellers IGA.  Pours a clear copper with an inch-thick beige head.  Aroma of sweet and roasted malts, toast, caramel, cherry, apple, spice, and hops.  Flavor is sweet caramel malts, cherry, apple, light hops, spice, and brown sugar.  Light-medium body, moderate carbonation, and crisp.  Sweet, smooth, and simple.  Nice beer.

Pours a medium bodied amber with an off white bubbly head. Spicy hops aromas, some light fruit, roasted malts, and caramel. Flavor is a little nutty, roasted malt, caramel, with a little toffee. Not bad.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a light amber color with a medium rocky off white head.  The aroma is lightly roasted malt, some caramel, and mildly earthy.  The flavor is moderately sweet malt, light roast, light caramel, bready, with some earthy hops. Medium bodied.   A decent, but middle of the road kind of beer.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 12oz bottle into a pint glass. 

Appearance: The body has light amber honey color with very good clarity. On top it forms a big creamy off white colored head. The head slowly fades but hangs on well and make cool rings of lace on the glass. 

Smell: The aroma is mostly sweet with hints of lightly roasted grains, bready yeast, light hops and some mild fruit notes. 

Taste/Mouth Feel: Its flavor has a good solid medium body with a sweet malty character that is tempered with just enough leafy hops for some balance. There are notes of bread, light caramel malt, orange marmalade and mild hops. The palate is smooth, slightly slick and easy drinking with mellow carbonation.

Notes: I love Great Lakes and this is one of my favorites. I also converted my mother and step father to craft beer with this Irish Ale! How cool is that!!!
Very smooth and malty.  no bad aftertaste.  pleasurable overall.  A verry nice sesion beer.  yum yum yum.

Appearance:  fairly textbook; reddish amber; low off-white head

Aroma:  lacks intensity but the expected aromas are present:  moderate malt, slightly toasty caramel, possibly with a touch of butter

Flavor:  has a toastiness, also caramel malt and a bread or popcorn note; pretty appetizing

Mouthfeel:  medium-light body; mild carbonation; quite smooth texture; enjoyable

12oz bottle.  Rating skewed, as the beer is being consumed a week after its est by date.  Filtered tan-orange color.  Fluffy soapy head.  The aroma is all malt, some amber in there Id assume.  Sweet and pretty one-dimensional, Im not very impressed.  Good session beer for the malt maniac, but lacks any praise-worthy complexities.
12oz bottle bonus from fiver29, thanks man!  Pours a clear medium copper color with a one finger thick off white head.  Nose and flavor were mostly toasted malts with a very light hope character.
draft at paninis.  the food was subpar, the music was terrible.  The ambiance may have affected this beers rating.
Not bad for an irish style red ale.  Nice head and good lacing.  Slightly roasted aroma and flavor of unsweet tea.  Overall above average.

Bottle thanks to Mike B., thanks man!

Beer pours a reddish/brown hue with a short lasting head.  I picked up lots of malts and toffee/carmel in the aroma.  The finish improves as the beer warms as the carbonation is a little to prickly at first.  Not a bad beer but nothing extraordinary.

medium sweetness, lightly bitter, caramel, nuts, citrus, banana, amber-orange color, minimal head, medium body, average carbonation, long finish, overall worth trying, not a stand out beer but i would recommend if asked.

Enjoyed via draft/bottle.  Pours a nice copper with a slight white head.  Initial nose is malty but clean, nearly sterile.  One gets some malt on the palate.  Hops serve only to balance the malt.  Finish is clean.  Overall, a nice American interpretation of a style that is simple, clean, and unremarkable.

Im glad a friend saved me one of these at a neighborhood party to enjoy before having Labatt and Bud the rest of the night.  The color was golden orange. The head was thin, fizzy, and white. The aroma was sweet and malty. The flavor was sweet, lightly hopped, and crisp malt. The palate was thin-bodied and lightly carbonated with a clean finish.

Bottle. Pours a deep amber, almost brown golden color and a medium white head.  Aroma is heavy in malts and a slight, slight hop smell.  Taste is medium bodied malty character, and a somewhat sour or hoppy flavor towards the end.  Overall it is a smooth taste and finish.

12oz. bottle in a lager glass.
Very light aroma.  Great reddish-orange color with an off-white head that is moderately short-lasting.  Mildly bitter beginning with a good, toasty finish that develops slowly after swallowing.  Light, thin body but not a light flavor..  Good beer thats definitely worth getting.

(bottle - 12 oz) Rich amber color with a fluffy white head. Aroma is very malty with some smoke, toffee, and lots of malts. Flavor begins with a mild sweetness mixed with a roasty and lightly bitter middle. Finishes clean with some smoke and caramel malts.

Reddish brown pour with the smell of tea and caramel. Notes of malt, grain, and maybe toffee..the lightest hint of hops sneaking in. Well balanced, not complex at all. Good I guess for drinking with dinner.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2010 Pours gorgeous red-tinged amber. Small bone head fades to mild lacing.  Subtly sweet, smooth, good flavor profile, full mouthfeel.  Great balance between the moderate roastiess and moderate hoppiness. Highly drinkable.
bottle. pours an amber color with little head. has a nice roasted, warm aroma. has a flavor of caramel and malt. very smooth and easy to drink.
From bottle... poured amber with medium white head. Sweet, malty aroma. Flavor of toasted malts. Smooth, slightly sweet finish. Pretty good.
Bottle. Pours orange amber with a beige head. Sweet aroma, toasty as well, with a light hop presence. The flavor is well balanced with toasty caramel malt and some nice earthy hop notes. Pretty good.

12 ounce bottle shared by cdumler. Thanks! Pours a clear reddish orange color with a medium head.  head retention and lacing. Fine carbonation is visible. Aroma is fruity with notes of apricot, caramel and nuts. Taste is elementary school fruit cocktail... peach, pineapple, syrup and whatnot. Also caramel and some faint earthy notes. Full bodied,

Draft pint at Chappys in Dayton.  Red and clean with a moderate head that slid away quickly.  Caramel aroma, sweet on the nose.  Robust toasty malt with a definitive sweet caramel pull over the top.  (#3504, 2/12/2009)
draft at jerrys sandwiches. lots of malty flavor, with some toastiness. just a touch of hops. super easy to drink. another solid beer from great lakes.

On tap. Pours clear amber red with a small white head which thins quickly.  Aroma of malt, bread, hint of hops.  Taste is caramel malt, yeast, a touch of hops in the finish.  Medium bodied with good balance.  Nice Red.

On tap at the Winking Lizard.  Pours a clear reddish amber with a thin white head.  Malty aroma with some bready yeast and hop.  Sweet malt flavor with some cherry, caramel and a nice hop finish that is atypical to this style.  Me likey.
tap Toledo bar (Blarney) - pretty tasty ale - kinda resembled an IPA at first.  good malts but not overly smooth.  not bad

Great Lakes Conways Irish Red Ale is a clear amber ale with a fading white head. It has a slightly sweet aroma thats a little resiny. It is medium bodied, smooth, bubbly, and the finish is clean. It is simple and balanced, with notes of resin, smoke and peat. It has a good bitterness and a touch of sweetness. Not bad.

Woop! Awesome brew! Sampled from bottle this, tastey beer pours a clear but illuminating orange colour with a finger sized off white head. Decent amount of lacing that slides itself down the glass into the big pool of froth. Aroma is very earthy, honey, light roasted malts and maybe some vanilla on the nose as well. Taste is almost peaty- malty but well balanced. Mouthfeel is light, but firm, and creamy. Definately pick this one up!

Poured a crystal clear red-amber color with an off-white head.  Caramel malt sweetness with some notes of toffee and light fruit.  Malty flavor with toffee and a touch of nuttiness.  Mild hop finish.  Light to medium bodied.
I really enjoyed this offering from Great Lakes. Had a sweet flavor but had enough bitter kick from the hops. It smelled so good, and had a great appearence.

This was very good and it was no surprise.  Good roasted bready taste that finished smooth with enough hops.  Good dark red color.  It was pretty thick too, or at least had a good body to it.  Only thing that too away from it was a smell that wasnt too strong, but i can live with that for the most part.

Copper pour with a nice head. Aroma of cereal malts, some spice. Flavor is malty with the signature weird great lakes flavor. It would be really funny if I went to the brewery and none of these beers had this weird flavor and Id been getting bad bottles all this time.

Pours a nice clear copper color with a thin white head.  Aroma of sweet malts.  Flavor starts malty with a watery toffee taste to it.  Ending flavor had some hops in it.  Dull flavor that could be more but falls just short, almost bland.  Nice and smooth nearly full bodied with slight bite at the end.

12oz - Nice tan head, copper colored liquid, malty bread nose.  On the sip malt strength.  Nice to this point, and then it all goes wrong.  Nasty sweet cabbage funk follows.  Another miss from Great Lakes for this taster.

Pint Glass
Pours a red amber, with a small white head.  Aroma of nutty dark chocolate, toasty hazelnut.  Light palate, with dull flavors matching the nose.  Oily in the mouth and on the finish.  Meh.

Bottle@Home. Toffee, molasses, fruity, light floral aroma. Amber color, beige head, good lace. Very sweet, malty, licorice wood, toffee, light bitter, floral, fruity. Very full and sticky mouthfeel. Nice and flavorful but due to the sweetness I wouldn’t know if I would have second.

Great red color with medium head and carbonation.  Aroma is very malty with a very prune fruit scent.  Flavor is moderate alcohol combined with a fruity prune, lots of malt character, very sweet hops and not much bitterness.  Overall a great example of a red.

I’ve only had this bottled, but I live close enough to the brewery to go try some on tap and the bottled version is good enough that I plan to do that soon. Dark amber pour, nice head, lovely clean taste. Reminds me of Smithwyck’s, only better, in my opinion.

Poured on tap at The Galway Tribes (Frankfort, IL). Pours a deep dark auburn hue with notes of dark red throughout with a small white head that quickly subsides. Aromas are largely malty, toasted malts and caramel break through with a minor hop presence. Initial is largely caramel malt sweetness. Taste moves to a slight hoppiness that is still smothered by the caramel malt. Not very complex as any complexity that may have existed is humped into submission by the toasted caramel malts. Finishes smooth and leaves the aftertaste ever present on the palate. Decent.. not something I’d necessarily go out of my way to try again though.

Bottle acquired via polomagnifico!!!  Yes, another one!!!  Thanks RYAN!!!  Aroma reveals nothing but sugar.  The appearance is bronze in color with a head that leaves only a small ring behind.  Flavor is where this one earns its merit badge (and isnt that the most important attribute???"  Incredible nuttiness, caramel, molasses, and toffee.  Palate is right down the middle.  Will warm ya during a winter chill.

12 oz bottle courtesy Polomagnifico. Pours a dark amber with a thick tan head. Big caramel malt, bread, earthy hop aroma. Taste is smooth and malty, toasty with just a touch of hop bitterness. Nice easy drinking ale that would be a nice session beer if it were available locally.
Pours a dark amber color with a large white head. Aroma was very malty with some bread notes. Flavor was also very malty but with a little bit of citrus hops to balance this very good irish ale.

12oz. Bottle:  A bit of a gusher.  Sweet aroma.  Smells of bread, malts, caramel, toasting, butterscotch and a bit of nuts.  Poured amber in color with a very large, dense, tan head that lasted throughout.  Clear.  Sparkling.  Very good lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet.  Tastes of malts, caramel, bread, toasting, cream, and a little butterscotch.  Medium body.  Average texture.  Average carbonation.  Malty finish is a bit sweet.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2008 12oz bottle.  Aroma has notes of caramel, toasted malt, toasted bread, some earthiness to it as well.  Clear medium red/amber hue with an average sized foamy off-white/tan head that mostly diminished and left little lace.  Flavor is malty caramel, toast, earth, and finishes noticeably bitter.  Palate is light bodied and watery soft.  Not bad for the style.  I liked it better than an amber ale but its still nothing outstanding.  Just a solid brew and very good representation of the style.

Bottle. Pretty good Irish Ale. Not usually a big fan as they are usually pretty average styled beers. This is one of the better though. Amber pour with malty bready aroma. Fits the style & thats all you can ask for
Bottle from Canals. Amber pour with thin white head. An essence of sweet malt and hop. Flavor was pretty much the same with a yeasty bread finish. It was just ok for me.

Another good selection from GLBC, this is about as textbook irish ale as you can find.

Pours a clean copper with a moderate not-quite-white head.  The aroma is immediately malt with hints of roasted nuts, toast, and just a bit of dark fruit.  

The taste is much the same, very noticeable again are the roasty toasty malt notes with the faint fruity hops becoming more apparent as the beer warms.

It finished relatively dry and clean with almost no lingering to speak of.  Very textbook....but in a good way.

Deep copper colored pour with a 1 finger, off-white head, and nice lacing.  Roasted caramel malt aroma with notes of wet oak and dark fruit.  Lots of dark caramel malt and pitted fruit flavor up front with a slightly floral hop finish and lingering toasted malt.  Medium body.

Picked up a single 12-oz bottle from Bob McFarlands Liquors in McFarland, Wisconsin. Pours a clear copper amber brew with a thin off-white head that quickly dissipates to a fine film and no ring. Aroma of light caramel malt, some flowery and grassy hops and a touch of pear. Taste is slightly dry, a roasted caramel malt character with some citrus and ice tea flavors. Finish is semi-dry with a mild bitterness that quickly disappears.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2008 Pours nice burnt orange, with off white head. Aroma is malty, creamy, sweet and a hint of citrus.  Very well balanced beer, sweet and sticky toasty malts, with a light hop presence. Very good beer, definitely grew on me as I drank it.

Bottle at Mongolian Wok.  Very malty nose with raspberry.  Mellow smoky palate, very sweet, complex, oaky, malty.  Better by far as it warms.  Very low on the hop count but the sweetness does not overwhelm.  Very enjoyable.

Thanks to miketd for this one.
Nice looking brew, clear dark amber pour with a thin white head, the flavor is malty sweet.
Very nice little brew from the Great Lake boys....  Deliciously malty with a hint of fruitness on the finish...  Beautiful to look at in the glass...  A good Irish ale..
A Mes rate: Bottle at Toms UGT Pt. 2.For some reason I didnt write any notes for this one. I think you can tell from my numbers I wasnt exactly enamoured with it...

Bottle from miketd.  Amber with a quickly dissapating cream colored head.  Aroma is lightly malty with a nuttiness to it with some caramel.  Taste is sweet up front complimented by a very faint hoppiness, faint cinnamon to it along with caramel.  Good stuff.

A fine ale: body is full, attractive color, refined aroma, and good flavor composition.  Strong malty toast and almond flavor.  Light hop spiciness comes in at the middle, but fades during the aftertaste.  Some fruitiness too, like dates or figs.  Or raisins, there is definitely some raisin in there.
Pours a clear deep orange-red with a smallish head. Aroma of sweet raspberries and dry roasted malt. Flavor is sweet malt and dough. Medium,long somewhat dry finish. Low carbonation.

Thanks miketd. Pours copper reddish amber with a thin beige head. The aroma was sweet, malty, a little grassy. The flavor was malty, toasty, bready, a little grassy, a good malt presence, a bit earthy. The mouthfeel was surprisingly satisfying, a full malty mouthfeel and a nice refreshing carbonation. Finishes toasty and sweet.

The color was golden orange.  The head was thin, fizzy, and white.  The aroma was sweet and crisp malt.  The flavor was sweet, lightly hopped, and crisp malt.  The palate was thin-bodied and lightly carbonated.  The finish was clean.
Bottle at the cads dance off disco. Alround rating: Soda water is key here, malty red ale backbone, floural hop, passes me by. Soda water was picked up by eveeryone there which seems strange?
Bottle at Toms Glasgow tasting 2 ... Copper ... yeasty bready malt nose ... sweet fruity bread very light metalic edge but again a bit plain. Wouldnt notice the 6.5%

On tap at Buffalo Wild Wings, Greensburg.  Pours a deep amber red color with a foamy 1-finger head.  Has a lot of sweet toffee and a bit of fruit in the aroma.  Some alcohol as well.  A strange malted peach flavor with some caramel and a noticeable bitterness.  A decent oily mouthfeel without a whole lot of carbonation.

12oz bottle: Ruby caramel pour with a nice head.  The nose is really earthy, with bready malts abound.  Medium bodied offering lots of caramel, sweet dough, sublte cocoa and dirty straw.  Esthery yeast adds a second layer of peach and cherry to the finish.  Interesting style to build a bigger beer from.

Bottle.  Pours a nice pure copper color with a one-finger off-white head.  Very little aroma.  Nice full malty flavor with a somewhat bitter finish.  Not bad, a nice change of pace from the more complex flavored beers.

a nice clear copper-colored brew, with a thin whitish head. malty foremost, with a hint of balancing hops and some toasty and roasty aromas as well.  some darker grains present themselves first, with caramel and dunkel flavors appearing after.  not a cloying finish, just sweet.  enjoyable and easy-drinking.

12oz bottle.  Amber/red with large bubbly head that fades fast.  Toasted malt and caramel on the nose and a nice smooth & balanced (though light on) flavor of  buttery caramel with a bitter peppery finish.
dark amber with white head.  flavor is pale and caramal malt with little hop flavor.  nice version of a boring style
Dark amber pour with off white head, great malty flavor and nice arrangement of hops. Very easy to drink. Tasted great with pizza.

Very faint aroma. Light malty flavor, a little nutty. Drinkable, not terrible but far from interesting, and a little too strong to session. Seems like its in a no mans land, in terms of what its doing.
Thanx to beervirgin for this brew.Pours copper with a small white head. Has a nutty, toastypeat nose on this.Semi sweet nuts and caramel flavor.A malty full mouthfeel finish.

Pours a medium crimson-orange color with a fizzy, off-white head.  Spotty lacing slowly oozes back down into the body.  The aroma is comprised of toasted caramel malts, fresh bread, subtle dark fruits and mild floral hops.  The flavor is sweet, yet sufficiently toasty.  Caramel is met by toasted bread, sweet yeast, cream and floral notes.  The hop component is such that it takes a back seat to the light malts, adding just enough bitterness to counteract some of the sweetness.  Just shy of medium bodied, this one tends to get a bit sticky after a while.  Great Lakes tends to do these lighter styles very well, and this is no exception, though it is far from a special brew.  Solid Irish Ale.

Had this on tap at a sportsbar back at school 2 nights ago.  Solid beer, but pretty mellow; its nothing to avoid and yet nothing to write home about.  Poured a slightly hazy honey gold with apparent carbonation (no head though because -- remember -- I was at a crappy sports bar).  One of the lesser great lakes but still a good safety beer.
A tasting at Three Callers Milwaukee. Bold and VERY flavorful. Rich and smooth you dont even notice the alcohol rate !
i thought it was christmas not st pattys day when i tasted this irish ale.  great flavor, aroma, and appearance a must have if youre in the mood for an irish beer

Bottle courtesy nolankowal...thanks!!  Pours an orangey red color with a moderate whitish head.  Aroma is very pleasant and pretty robust for an Irish Ale...mostly (caramel) malt with some roasted nuts and hoppy accents.  Flavor is well balanced for the style...the backbone is caramel, roasted nuts, but theres some hop bitterness and fruit accents to keep things interesting!  A bit dry on the finish for my tastes, but the mouthfeel is very good and coats the palate.  I gotta keep trying the goods from Great Lakes...they put some quality brews out there!
Pours amber with a medium off white head.  Aroma is faint, but of pale malts.  Taste is a grainy mix of pale and roasted malts.  Not a bad irish ale.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2009 Draft at Jerrys Sandwiches. Pours a deep red with a nice, floral nose that is a touch fruity as well. My favorite part about this beer is that there really isnt much of a crystal malt character, but it is still quite malt forward. Tasty stuff.
Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a small off white head. Aroma of nuts, bananas, malt and caramel. Taste of rye, caramel, fermented fruits and nuts. Has a dry slightly tart finish.
Tap pours a typical Irish Red.  Smells like a malty beer with a small hop nose.  No lacing.  Tastes like a good solid Irish Ale and with good malt backbone.  Nothing too special except its a GL.

bottle. pours clear copper with whitehead. nose is extremely nutty with bready, toasted biscuit. flavor is slightly sour, why do i taste peanut butter? weird, and toasted biscuit, rotten fruit. this just isnt fun to drink.

Pours an amber red color, with a white (and quickly repelling) head. Smells of malts and grain, a little chocolatey goodness evident as well. Tasted great, nothing overpowering, but the carmel, malt, and hops seemed to have blended well. Its got an average body to it, nothing overpowering; nothing outstanding. All in all this was another solid beer from Great Lakes. I would drink this again (and have) if it were available, but I dont think this would be something I would intentionaly seek out.

Serving type: bottle

Had this one on draught at Bennigans in St. Charles, Illinois.  Clear, medium orange pour with a pretty thick, long lasting light orange head, nose of buttery malts and sweet caramel.  Milky, full mouthfeel.  Taste is sweet, malty, with molassas, apple, and a touch of citrus.  Soft finish.  Very nice.

Bottle from Sergios - Pours amber with a thin wispy tan head. Aroma of crackery malt, caramel, herbal, bready, and toffee notes. Taste is toffee, fruity and lightly resinous hops, sweet wort, light pear and banana esters and caramel. Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with moderate carbonation. A bit hoppier than I was expecting, but still pretty good.
Excellent session beer with an enjoyable toasted malt flavor with a slight hop finish.  My only complaint is that is not available year round.
Pours dark amber with few bubbles and small off-white head.  Sweet malt caramel aroma.  Toasty buttery malts with some crisp hops on the finish.  Similar to an english pale.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2013 Draft at Jerrys. Amber with big, foamy, off-white head / Sweet nose of spun sugar, bread, and citrus / Light to medium body, creamy, sweet and lightly syrupy, somewhat malty with modest hopping, and sweet finish / Simple, clean flavors of spun sugar, honey, and bread, with notes of orange peel / A pleasant and easy drinker, a touch overly sweet for my taste.
Beautiful red color with a thin white head. Mild malty taste with a dry, fully-hopped finish. Pretty good, but not earth-shattering.

12oz best by 3/21/08.  Pours a light amber red with a big foamy white head that leaves nice lacing down the glass.  Aroma is that signature Great Lakes burnt malt character that is sometimes pleasant and sometimes distracting - here it fits in nice.  Some graininess and toastiness is also noted.  Reminds me a lot of the Eliot Ness.  Flavor is pretty rich, caramely.  Very smooth and easy to drink.  Medium bodied, low bitterness, with a grainy finish.  While this certainly is not going to blow anyone away I find it quite appetizing and like many Great Lakes beers something I wouldnt mind drinking a lot of in one sitting.  Very good.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2010 Very refreshing. Not many irish ales available from the US. Caramel finish. Hints of toffee and tea leaves. Clean finish. I could drink six of these with ease. Worth trying if you are a fan of the brewery.

12oz bottle. Poured a medium to deeper amber color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of caramel, toasted malts, and lightly earthy. Tastes of caramel and toasted malts. Lots of caramel in the flavor.
The roasted caramel flavor is much more prevalent with this Irish ale than say, Killians.  Well done.
Solid Irish ale. Too bad it only comes out once a year around St. Patricks Day. Clean palate and clean finish. One of my favorite beers
A solid Irish style ale. Moderately complex flavor - crisp clean palate. clean finish.

Name: Conways Irish Ale
Date: 04/08/2006
Mode: Bottle
Source: Trade

clear dark amber, thin off white head, sweet carmel malt aroma and flavor, low bitterness

Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20
Rating: 2.6/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
